description.short: Measures vulnerability created when organizations unconsciously divide security threats into oversimplified 'trusted internal' versus 'dangerous external' categories
description.context: Organizational splitting occurs when organizations unconsciously divide security threats into oversimplified 'trusted internal' versus 'dangerous external' categories. This binary thinking creates dangerous blind spots by over-trusting insiders and systems while projecting all risk onto external attackers. Organizations experiencing splitting exhibit extreme trust in certain actors (long-term employees, vendors, executives) while attributing security failures exclusively to sophisticated external threats, making them vulnerable to insider attacks and social engineering.
description.impact: Organizations with high splitting vulnerability experience trusted insider data theft exploiting idealized status, social engineering attacks leveraging trust transfer mechanisms, supply chain infiltration through inadequate vendor scrutiny, and lateral movement exploitation through implicit trust assumptions. Historical incidents include Edward Snowden case where extreme trust in cleared personnel enabled massive data exfiltration, Target breach where trust in HVAC vendor credentials enabled network infiltration, and SolarWinds attack exploiting organizational trust in software update processes.
description.psychological_basis: Klein's Object Relations Theory (1946) identifies splitting as primitive defense mechanism where ego cannot tolerate ambivalence about objects that are both good and bad. In organizational contexts, this translates to inability to hold anxiety-provoking reality that trusted insiders can pose security risks. Bion (1961) demonstrated how groups under anxiety adopt basic assumptions that distort reality. Modern neuroscience supports Klein's observations with amygdala activation creating rapid categorization of stimuli as threatening or safe, with stress increasing brain's tendency toward binary categorization.

scoring.formula: Final_Score = (w1 Ã— Quick_Assessment + w2 Ã— Conversation_Depth + w3 Ã— Red_Flags) Ã— Interdependency_Multiplier

green.label: Low Vulnerability - Resilient
green.description: Balanced trust assessment with comprehensive incident investigation including internal factors, active monitoring of all privileged users regardless of role, security policies applied uniformly with minimal exceptions, balanced security budget allocation with minimum 30% focused on insider threat detection.

yellow.label: Moderate Vulnerability - Developing
yellow.description: Moderate splitting indicators with most incidents investigated but some automatic external attribution, privileged user monitoring exists but with gaps for certain trusted categories, security policy exceptions granted regularly with some oversight, different security standards for different personnel tiers.

red.label: High Vulnerability - Critical
red.description: High splitting vulnerability with incidents consistently attributed to external attackers without internal investigation, minimal monitoring of privileged users especially executives, frequent policy exceptions for trusted personnel, significantly different security standards based on perceived trust levels.

splitting_polarization.description: Measures degree of polarized thinking about specific entities (people, systems, vendors)

splitting_index.formula: SI(t) = (1/n) Ã— Î£|SP(entity_i)| where n = count of monitored entities
splitting_index.description: Aggregate organizational splitting tendency across all monitored entities

variables.n: number of entities being assessed (users, systems, vendors)
variables.SP_entity: splitting polarization score for each entity

trust_imbalance.description: Measures imbalance between external threat focus and internal trust assumptions
trust_imbalance.interpretation: High values indicate external threat fixation combined with internal exception rate

temporal_decay.description: Exponential smoothing with 2-hour time constant for splitting pattern detection

attribution_bias_score.description: Percentage of incidents automatically attributed to external sophisticated attackers
attribution_bias_score.interpretation: Values exceeding 0.7 indicate splitting-driven attribution bias

SP.calculation: Splitting polarization for each entity based on positive vs negative assessments
SP.query: SELECT entity, ABS(SUM(CASE WHEN sentiment='positive' THEN 1 ELSE 0 END) - SUM(CASE WHEN sentiment='negative' THEN 1 ELSE 0 END)) / COUNT(*) as SP FROM entity_assessments WHERE timestamp > NOW() - INTERVAL '90 days' GROUP BY entity

SI.calculation: Average splitting index across all monitored entities
SI.query: SELECT AVG(ABS(positive_count - negative_count) / (positive_count + negative_count)) FROM entity_polarization_summary WHERE assessment_date > NOW() - INTERVAL '30 days'

ABS.calculation: Percentage of incidents attributed to external actors
ABS.query: SELECT (COUNT(attribution='external') / COUNT(*)) FROM incidents WHERE incident_date > NOW() - INTERVAL '6 months'

sections.title: QUICK ASSESSMENT

items.title: Incident Root Cause Attribution Process
items.question: When your organization experiences a security incident or breach, what is your standard process for determining the root cause? Tell us about a specific recent incident and how the investigation concluded.

options.label: All security incidents undergo comprehensive investigation including both internal factors and external attack vectors with documented analysis
Most incidents investigated thoroughly but some automatic attribution to external attackers without deep internal analysis
Security incidents consistently attributed to external sophisticated attackers without systematic investigation of internal contributing factors

items.evidence_required: Incident investigation reports showing attribution analysis, root cause documentation
items.soc_mapping: ABS metric (Attribution Bias Score) from detection_formula

items.title: Privileged User Activity Monitoring
items.question: How often does your organization actively monitor the activities of privileged users (administrators, executives, long-term employees) for potential security risks? What specific monitoring tools or processes are in place for internal personnel?

options.label: Active monitoring systems track all privileged user activities regardless of role or tenure with baseline behavior analysis
Privileged user monitoring exists but with explicit gaps for certain 'trusted' categories like executives or long-term employees
Minimal or no monitoring of privileged users, especially for executives, long-term employees, or other 'trusted' categories

items.evidence_required: UEBA coverage documentation, privileged user monitoring policies, monitoring scope by user category
items.soc_mapping: Privileged user monitoring coverage from user_behavior_analytics

items.title: Security Policy Exception Management
items.question: What is your procedure when senior executives, long-term employees, or trusted vendors request exceptions to standard security policies? Give us a recent example of such a request and how it was handled.

options.label: Security policies apply uniformly with documented, limited exceptions requiring formal approval regardless of requestor status
Security policy exceptions granted regularly but with some oversight process, different standards for different roles
Frequent security policy exceptions for 'trusted' personnel with minimal oversight or documentation

items.evidence_required: Exception request logs by requestor category, approval workflows, specific recent examples

items.title: Access Control Consistency
items.question: How does your organization determine access levels for different personnel categories (executives, IT staff, regular employees, contractors, vendors)? Tell us about your specific process and any differences in security requirements between these groups.

options.label: Similar access controls and verification requirements for all personnel categories based on job function rather than trust level
Different security standards exist for different personnel tiers with documented rationale
Significantly different security standards based on perceived trust levels with minimal verification for 'trusted' categories

items.evidence_required: Access control matrices by role category, verification requirement documentation
items.soc_mapping: Access control variance analysis from access_control_system

items.title: Insider Threat Investment Balance
items.question: What percentage of your security budget is allocated to external threat detection (firewalls, perimeter security) versus internal threat monitoring (user behavior analytics, insider threat detection)? Provide specific budget breakdowns.

options.label: Balanced security budget allocation with minimum 30% focused on insider threat detection and internal monitoring
Budget allocation shows preference for perimeter security but some insider threat investment (15-29%)
Security budget heavily focused on external threats with less than 15% allocated to insider threat detection

items.evidence_required: Security budget breakdown by threat category, insider threat program funding documentation

items.title: Trusted Vendor Security Reassessment
items.question: How frequently does your organization reassess the security practices of long-term, trusted vendors or partners? Give us an example of when you last changed security requirements for an established vendor relationship.

options.label: Regular security reassessments of all vendors including long-term trusted partners with documented review cycles
Vendor assessments occur but less frequently for established relationships than new vendors
Established vendor relationships rarely reassessed for security, 'trusted partner' status persists without validation

items.evidence_required: Vendor security assessment schedules, reassessment frequency by vendor tenure, recent requirement changes

items.title: Zero Trust Implementation Coverage
items.question: To what extent has your organization implemented zero trust security principles (verify every user and device, regardless of location or perceived trust level)? Tell us specifically which systems or personnel are exempt from verification requirements and why.

options.label: Comprehensive zero trust implementation with minimal exceptions and continuous verification for all users and systems
Partial zero trust implementation with exceptions for certain systems or roles based on trust assumptions
Zero trust principles rejected or implemented with major exceptions for 'trusted' entities

items.evidence_required: Zero trust architecture documentation, exception lists, verification requirement coverage
items.soc_mapping: Zero trust coverage analysis from access_control_system

sections.instructions: Select ONE option for each question. Each answer contributes to the weighted final score. Evidence should be documented for audit trail.

items.text: Walk me through how you investigate security incidents. What's your process for determining whether internal factors contributed alongside external attacks?

scoring_guidance.green: Systematic investigation of both external attack vectors and internal vulnerabilities, documented analysis of internal factors in all incidents, recent examples showing balanced attribution
scoring_guidance.yellow: Most incidents investigated but tendency toward external attribution, internal factors sometimes examined but not systematically
scoring_guidance.red: Consistent pattern of external attribution with language like 'sophisticated attacker,' 'advanced persistent threat' without examining internal vulnerabilities or insider involvement

followups.text: Show me the investigation report from your most recent security incident.
Have you ever concluded that an incident was primarily caused by internal factors rather than external attackers?

items.text: Tell me about your privileged user monitoring. Do you monitor executives, IT administrators, and long-term employees the same way you monitor regular users?

scoring_guidance.green: Comprehensive monitoring of all privileged users regardless of role, seniority, or tenure with documented baseline behaviors and anomaly detection
scoring_guidance.yellow: Monitoring exists but with acknowledged gaps for certain 'trusted' categories, rationalized as cultural sensitivity or business necessity
scoring_guidance.red: Different monitoring standards based on trust level, language like 'we trust our executives' or 'long-term employees don't need monitoring'

followups.text: Show me your UEBA coverage dashboard and explain any gaps in privileged user monitoring.
What would happen if your CEO's account showed anomalous behavior?

items.text: When senior executives or long-term trusted employees request exceptions to security policies, what's your typical response process?

scoring_guidance.green: Uniform exception process regardless of requestor with formal approval, risk assessment, and regular review
scoring_guidance.yellow: Exception process exists but different standards or faster approvals for certain 'trusted' requestors
scoring_guidance.red: Frequent automatic approval of exceptions for executives or trusted personnel with minimal documentation or oversight

followups.text: Show me your security exception logs for the past 6 months broken down by requestor category.
Have you ever denied an exception request from a senior executive? Tell me about it.

items.text: How do your access controls differ between executives, regular employees, and contractors? Walk me through the verification requirements for each category.

scoring_guidance.green: Consistent access controls based on job function rather than organizational status, similar verification requirements across categories
scoring_guidance.yellow: Some variation in requirements with documented rationale, generally consistent but some trust-based differences
scoring_guidance.red: Significantly different requirements based on perceived trust, executives or long-term employees exempt from normal verification

followups.text: Show me your access control matrices for different user categories.
Why do different categories have different security requirements?

items.text: What percentage of your security budget goes to insider threat detection versus external threat protection? Why this allocation?

scoring_guidance.green: At least 30% allocated to insider threat with documented risk assessment justifying balanced approach
scoring_guidance.yellow: 15-29% insider threat allocation with awareness of imbalance but operational focus on external threats
scoring_guidance.red: Under 15% insider threat investment with justifications like 'we trust our people' or 'internal threats aren't our main concern'

followups.text: Show me your security budget breakdown by threat category.
What would it take for you to increase insider threat investment?

items.text: How often do you reassess the security of your long-term trusted vendors? Tell me about your most recent vendor security review for an established partner.

scoring_guidance.green: Regular reassessment of all vendors regardless of relationship duration with documented review cycles and security requirement updates
scoring_guidance.yellow: Periodic assessments but less frequent for trusted partners, some acknowledgment that this creates risk
scoring_guidance.red: Trusted vendors rarely reassessed with language like 'we've worked with them for years' or 'they're a trusted partner'

followups.text: Show me your vendor security assessment schedule and completion records.
Have you ever tightened security requirements for a long-term vendor? Why?

items.text: Tell me about your zero trust implementation. Are there any users, systems, or networks that are considered 'trusted' and exempt from continuous verification?

scoring_guidance.green: Comprehensive zero trust with minimal exemptions, continuous verification regardless of user or system status
scoring_guidance.yellow: Partial zero trust with some exemptions based on trust assumptions, working toward fuller implementation
scoring_guidance.red: Major exemptions for 'trusted' entities, resistance to zero trust with concerns about 'not trusting our people'

followups.text: Show me your zero trust architecture and document the exemptions.
What concerns or resistance have you encountered implementing zero trust?

solutions.title: Behavioral Analytics Implementation
solutions.description: Deploy user and entity behavior analytics (UEBA) systems that monitor all personnel activities regardless of role or tenure
solutions.implementation: Implement baseline behavior modeling for privileged users, automated anomaly detection for unusual access patterns, and risk scoring for all internal actors. Establish clear escalation procedures for behavioral anomalies regardless of user status. Include executives, administrators, and long-term employees in comprehensive monitoring scope.
solutions.technical_controls: UEBA platform deployment, baseline behavior modeling, anomaly detection algorithms, risk scoring engine, escalation workflow automation

solutions.title: Zero Trust Architecture Deployment
solutions.description: Implement comprehensive zero trust principles requiring verification for all users and devices regardless of perceived trust level
solutions.implementation: Deploy multi-factor authentication for all system access, micro-segmentation of network resources, and continuous authentication for sensitive operations. Eliminate security policy exceptions based on role or tenure. Implement least privilege access controls uniformly across all user categories.
solutions.technical_controls: Zero trust network architecture, continuous authentication system, micro-segmentation implementation, MFA enforcement, least privilege automation

solutions.title: Insider Threat Program Development
solutions.description: Establish formal insider threat program with dedicated personnel and resources
solutions.implementation: Implement psychological evaluation for high-risk positions, regular security awareness training focused on insider risks, peer reporting mechanisms for concerning behaviors, and structured investigation processes for internal incidents. Create cross-functional insider threat working group.
solutions.technical_controls: Insider threat management platform, training delivery system, anonymous reporting portal, investigation workflow automation

solutions.title: Incident Response Process Enhancement
solutions.description: Revise incident response procedures to mandate comprehensive investigation of all security events including internal factors
solutions.implementation: Implement structured root cause analysis requiring examination of both external attack vectors and internal vulnerabilities. Establish independent incident review processes to prevent attribution bias. Create incident investigation templates ensuring balanced analysis.
solutions.technical_controls: Enhanced incident response playbooks, root cause analysis templates, independent review workflow, attribution tracking metrics

solutions.title: Access Control Matrix Standardization
solutions.description: Develop standardized access control matrices applying consistent security requirements across all personnel categories
solutions.implementation: Implement regular access reviews for all privileged accounts, automated provisioning and deprovisioning processes, and documented justification requirements for any access exceptions. Establish role-based access controls with principle of least privilege applied uniformly.
solutions.technical_controls: Access governance platform, automated access review workflows, exception tracking system, least privilege enforcement automation

solutions.title: Vendor Risk Management Program
solutions.description: Create comprehensive vendor risk management program with regular security assessments of all partners regardless of relationship duration
solutions.implementation: Implement continuous monitoring of vendor security postures, contractual security requirements for all vendors, and incident response coordination procedures. Establish vendor access controls with time-limited permissions and regular reassessment cycles.
solutions.technical_controls: Vendor risk management platform, continuous monitoring system, contract management with security clauses, vendor access governance

risk_scenarios.title: Trusted Insider Data Theft
risk_scenarios.description: Employees with idealized status (executives, long-term staff, privileged IT personnel) exploit their trusted position to exfiltrate sensitive data over extended periods
risk_scenarios.attack_vector: Gradual privilege escalation and data theft by trusted insiders exploiting monitoring blind spots
risk_scenarios.psychological_mechanism: Organizational splitting creates 'trusted' category exempt from normal security scrutiny
risk_scenarios.historical_example: Edward Snowden case - extreme trust in cleared personnel enabled massive data exfiltration without detection

risk_scenarios.title: Social Engineering via Trust Transfer
risk_scenarios.description: Attackers exploit the organization's splitting tendency by positioning themselves as 'trusted' through impersonation of authority figures, established vendors, or internal personnel
risk_scenarios.attack_vector: Social engineering leveraging organizational trust assumptions to bypass normal security scrutiny
risk_scenarios.psychological_mechanism: Once categorized as 'trusted,' attackers benefit from reduced security verification
risk_scenarios.historical_example: Target breach - trust in HVAC vendor credentials enabled network infiltration exploiting splitting between trusted and untrusted entities

risk_scenarios.title: Supply Chain Infiltration
risk_scenarios.description: Organizations with strong splitting patterns fail to adequately scrutinize trusted vendor relationships, enabling sophisticated supply chain attacks
risk_scenarios.attack_vector: Compromise of trusted partners or software providers exploiting 'trusted partner' blind spot
risk_scenarios.psychological_mechanism: Splitting between 'trusted vendors' and 'external threats' prevents adequate vendor scrutiny
risk_scenarios.historical_example: SolarWinds attack - organizations' trust in security software vendor enabled supply chain attack affecting 18,000+ customers

risk_scenarios.title: Lateral Movement Exploitation
risk_scenarios.description: Once inside the network perimeter, attackers exploit the organization's implicit trust assumptions to move laterally across systems
risk_scenarios.attack_vector: Internal network reconnaissance and lateral movement exploiting weak internal network segmentation
risk_scenarios.psychological_mechanism: Splitting creates assumption that internal network traffic is trustworthy
risk_scenarios.historical_example: Multiple APT campaigns exploiting weak internal segmentation after initial compromise, assuming external perimeter was sole security boundary
